results.headline: Dance, Fight, Laugh, Cry and Read Great Literature

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How She Move

results.summary_short: The strong acting, spectacular dance routines and culturally specific details in “How She Move” turn clichés into catharsis.

results.headline: In the City, Relationships Reduced to Transactions

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lost In Beijing

results.summary_short: At its heart, “Lost in Beijing” is a sturdy morality tale about innocence and corruption, wealth and want, sex and power.

results.headline: Gangsterism as Allegory for Life’s Basic Themes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Air I Breathe

results.summary_short: “The Air I Breathe” is an ingenious contraption that holds your attention for as long as it whirs and clicks like a mechanized Rubik’s Cube.

results.headline: Brutal, Painful Death, Just a Mouse Click Away

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Untraceable

results.summary_short: Morally duplicitous torture porn: how else to describe “Untraceable,” a bleak, rain-washed horror thriller.

results.headline: Comedy on Wheels

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trailer Park Boys: The Movie

results.summary_short: “Trailer Park Boys: The Movie” is like a feature-length version of the television sitcom “My Name Is Earl,” only Canadian — and not funny.

results.headline: Just When You Thought It Was Safe to Go Back in the Jungle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rambo

results.summary_short: “Rambo,” directed by and starring Sylvester Stallone, has its own kind of blockheaded poetry.

results.headline: More Than Rock ’n’ Roll: U2 on Tour in 3-D Images

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of U2 3D

results.summary_short: The musical documentary “U2 3D,” which stitches together three performances by this Irish rock band, is  the first Imax movie that deserves to be called a work of art.

results.headline: A Writer and Speaker Specializing in Everything

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Doc

results.summary_short: “Doc,” a nonfiction feature about the life of the novelist, inventor and cult figure Harold Louis Humes, is one part cultural analysis, three parts home movie.

results.headline: Taking a Long, Bumpy Ride to Systematic Brutality

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Taxi to the Dark Side

results.summary_short: If recent American history is ever going to be discussed with the necessary clarity and ethical rigor, “Taxi to the Dark Side” will be essential.

results.headline: Those Days of Doom on the Yangtze

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Still Life

results.summary_short: In “Still Life,” the blood and the sweat run directly into the Yangtze River, where they mingle with more than a few tears.

results.headline: Those Chaotic College Years in Beijing

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Summer Palace

results.summary_short: Lou Ye’s “Summer Palace” examines youthful idealism and its unhappy aftermath.

results.headline: Suddenly Called to Serve: A Dove, a Hawk and a Loon

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Day Zero

results.summary_short: If the abysmal reception so far for films about the war in Iraq is any indication, “Day Zero” is the last thing movie audiences will want to consume.

results.headline: Things They Don’t Teach in Any Dental School

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Teeth

results.summary_short: Teenage horror-movie spoof, John Waters parody, No Nukes protest movie: Mitchell Lichtenstein’s clever, crude comedy, “Teeth,” is all these and more.

results.headline: In Over Their Heads, With Destiny Looming

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cassandra's Dream

results.summary_short: “Cassandra’s Dream,” Woody Allen’s latest excursion to the dark side of human nature, is good enough that you may wonder why he doesn’t just stop making comedies once and for all.

results.headline: Israeli Soldiers Man a Fortress of Futility

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beaufort

results.summary_short: “Beaufort” may be, strictly speaking, a war movie, but for long stretches it feels more like science fiction.

results.headline: Bank’s Trash Is Treasure for Grabbing

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mad Money

results.summary_short: In the breezy, amoral heist comedy “Mad Money,” “Fun With Dick and Jane” meets “9 to 5” on the way to recession.

results.headline: Bridesmaid Revisited, Again and Again

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 27 Dresses

results.summary_short: “27 Dresses” makes the point that modern American weddings are all pretty much alike. The same could be said about modern American romantic comedies.

results.headline: We’re All Gonna Die! Grab Your Video Camera!

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cloverfield

results.summary_short: “Cloverfield” is nominally a monster movie, but mostly it’s a feature-length gimmick.

results.headline: Unrest, a Love Triangle and Swinging Hips

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Opera Jawa

results.summary_short: A colorful and confounding head trip, “Opera Jawa” is guaranteed to test the fortitude of all but the most adventurous viewer.

results.headline: Magic and Mayhem From a Video Game
results.display_title: In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale

results.summary_short: Like actors in an amateur stage play, the large, mostly all-star — or has-been star — cast of “In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale” look, rather dazedly, to be playing dress-up.
